description: Fundamental biological concepts including cells, DNA, animal kingdoms, and evolution for scientific reasoning
author: Bryan A. Spruk

entries.definition: Basic components and functions of eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells
examples: Plant cells have cell walls and chloroplasts
Bacterial cells are prokaryotic with no nucleus
Human cells contain specialized organelles for different functions

entries.definition: The process by which DNA makes a copy of itself during cell division

steps: DNA helicase unwinds the double helix
Lagging strand synthesized in fragments (Okazaki fragments)

examples: Semiconservative replication produces two DNA molecules
Each new molecule contains one original strand and one new strand
Errors in replication can lead to mutations

entries.definition: Classification system for animal diversity and characteristics
examples: Humans belong to kingdom Animalia, phylum Chordata, class Mammalia
Insects (Arthropoda) make up over 80% of animal species
Vertebrates have a backbone, invertebrates do not

entries.definition: Scientific theory explaining the diversity of life through natural selection and genetic change

key_concepts.natural_selection: organisms better adapted to environment survive and reproduce
key_concepts.adaptation: traits that improve survival and reproduction

examples: Peppered moths: dark forms became more common during industrial revolution
Antibiotic resistance: bacteria evolve resistance to antibiotics
Galapagos finches: beak shapes adapted to different food sources

entries.definition: Process by which plants and other organisms convert light energy into chemical energy

stages.light_dependent: produces ATP and NADPH using light energy
stages.light_independent: Calvin cycle uses ATP and NADPH to make glucose

key_components.stroma: fluid in chloroplasts where Calvin cycle occurs

examples: Plants use photosynthesis to produce food
Algae and some bacteria also perform photosynthesis
Oxygen released is essential for aerobic respiration

entries.definition: Process by which cells break down glucose to produce ATP energy

stages.glycolysis: breaks glucose into pyruvate, produces 2 ATP
stages.electron_transport: uses NADH/FADH₂ to produce ATP via oxidative phosphorylation

examples: Muscle cells use aerobic respiration during exercise
Yeast uses anaerobic respiration (fermentation) to make bread rise
Mitochondria are the primary site of cellular respiration
